title: ‘Dig your own grave I guess’: Boss forces specific employees to use PTO during a snowstorm instead of allowing them to work remotely
description: Workplaces managed to find a way to let their employees work remotely in the beginning of this decade. Now, that was necessary to ensure the safety of every employee that worked in close quarters with others. The explosion of remote work proved that a lot (if not all) of an employee's tasks could be completely remotely and be just as fruitful for the company they worked for.Many offices initiated an RTO (return to office) mandate to boost company morale. I won't act like I know if that truly makes a difference, but it's obvious that remote work is sought after by many folks in the workforce. There are pros and cons to remote work for sure, but the biggest pro is employee safety. When bad weather breaks out and you really don't want to use a PTO day, you can open your laptop and go about your daily tasks without difficulty.The southern US-based user who posted this next story doesn't particularly enjoy working from home, but they were hoping to get the green light from their manager when a freak snowstorm hit the area. Instead of getting the go-ahead, their boss told them if they don't want to come to the office, they are required to take a PTO day and the same goes for the rest of their department.The funny thing, though, is that other departments at the same company are allowed to work from home. Baffled, the user can't believe the company is willing to have their entire department go MIA instead of simply allowing them to work remotely and keep themselves safe off the road. I guess the company would rather sabotage employee output instead…
author: Lana DeGaetano
excerpt: ‘Dig your own grave I guess’: Boss forces specific employees to use PTO during a snowstorm instead of allowing them to work remotely - The internet has generated a huge amount of laughs from cats and FAILS. And we all out of cats.
text: At this point, the company is forcing the user's hand. If their entire department calls off on the same day, every other department that relies on them will suffer because of management's selfish choices. It's not like this employee is foaming at the mouth to work remotely—they even stated they don't really like being out of office! When their safety is at risk, though, they're willing to do what they have to. The same cannot be said for this company.PTO is like gold—once you have it, you want to hold onto it until you find some real use for it. The user is right to want to save up their vacation days for an actual vacation, rather than use it because they feel like they're being forced to. Even though what the company is doing is legal, it's unethical and illogical. Say the user's entire department decides to take the day off. For that entire day, they'll all be logged out of Microsoft Teams if daily company processes go awry… The company prefers to lie down and wither on this anti-WFH hill instead of making the remote policy fair for all departments. Well, if the boss says to take PTO, the user must oblige…
html:
At this point, the company is forcing the user's hand. If their entire department calls off on the same day, every other department that relies on them will suffer because of management's selfish choices. It's not like this employee is foaming at the mouth to work remotely—they even stated they don't really like being out of office! When their safety is at risk, though, they're willing to do what they have to. The same cannot be said for this company.

PTO is like gold—once you have it, you want to hold onto it until you find some real use for it. The user is right to want to save up their vacation days for an actual vacation, rather than use it because they feel like they're being forced to. Even though what the company is doing is legal, it's unethical and illogical. Say the user's entire department decides to take the day off. For that entire day, they'll all be logged out of Microsoft Teams if daily company processes go awry… 

The company prefers to lie down and wither on this anti-WFH hill instead of making the remote policy fair for all departments. Well, if the boss says to take PTO, the user must oblige…
